toc_entry.title: Heaven On Wheels
toc_entry.description: Why are we crazy for Cadillacs, silly on Suburbans, passionate about pickups? Because Texans love their cars, that's why.

toc_entry.title: The Double Life Of Paul Thayer
toc_entry.description: He had it all: a wife and a mistress, a limousine and a motorcycle, the secondhighest job at the Pentagon and some good-time Dallas buddies. Then the Sec took an interest in his life.

toc_entry.title: Blissed-Out On the Beach Of Love
toc_entry.description: At a slightly wacky hotel in southern Mexico, you can lose your inhibitions and find a little romance.

toc_entry.title: Age Of Innocents
toc_entry.description: Remember when children played dress-up in their own clothes? They still can.

toc_entry.title: The Night Crew
toc_entry.description: There are a hundred of them, and their job is invisibility. They come into giant office buildings after everyone has gone home and, if they do the job right, make the evidence of the day’s work disappear.

toc_entry.title: Pierre Was New In Town And Had Never Really Caught Anything Before
toc_entry.subtitle: Western Art
toc_entry.description: An interpretation of a classic genre.

toc_entry.title: The Permanent University Fund
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: In 1883 the University of Texas got stuck with two million acres of West Texas scrubland. Then it hit oil, and the money started rolling in.

toc_entry.title: My Quest For the Perfect Biscuit
toc_entry.description: It all started at my grandmother’s when I was seven years old. No biscuit has since measured up, but my lonely search for that sublime confection continues.

toc_entry.title: Grading the High Schools
toc_entry.subtitle: Education
toc_entry.description: Ut reports on how well students from Texas schools do.

toc_entry.title: How Do You Spell Real Estate?
toc_entry.subtitle: Business
toc_entry.description: Roger Staubach finds happiness by swapping Rolaids for real estate.

toc_entry.title: Prince Of Wails

toc_entry.description: Prince’s Purple Rain is short on plot and dialogue but long on fancy anguish; The Bostonians is a namby-pamby treatment of Henry James’ biting novel.

toc_entry.title: Tangled Lines
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: William Humphrey’s Hostages to Fortune tells a sodden fishing story; C. W. Smith’s The Vestal Virgin Room tells of an empty quest for fame; Rosemary Catacalos' Again for the First Time is an outstanding collection of verse.

toc_entry.title: Cut From the Herd
toc_entry.subtitle: Popular Music
toc_entry.description: Herd It Through the Grapevine, a new disc anthology, has the top of the pop crop.

toc_entry.title: Behind the Lines
toc_entry.description: On the edge of life.

toc_entry.title: The Roar Of the Crowd
toc_entry.description: Great cafe meals, dubious political deals, Luckenbach’s ideals.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective statewide guide to amusements and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: A new Henry Lee Lucas mystery in Lubbock; a sixties entrepreneur confronts the eighties; a foolish flap in Houston; an old way to travel across Texas.

toc_entry.title: Touts
